prefix: Approach the following question the way someone with a PhD in mathematics would.
problem_prompt: Approach the following question the way someone with a PhD in mathematics would. What is the base four equivalent of $123_{10}$?
solution: We know that $4^{4}>123_{10}>4^{3}$. So, we can tell that $123_{10}$ in base four will have four digits. $4^{3}=64$, which can go into 123 only one time at most, leaving $123-1\cdot64 = 59$ for the next three digits. $4^{2}=16$ goes into 59 three times at most, leaving us with $59-3\cdot16 = 11$. Then, $4^{1}=4$ goes into 11 two times at most, leaving $11-2\cdot4 = 3$ for the ones digit. All together, the base four equivalent of $123_{10}$ is $\boxed{1323_{4}}$.
gpt_response:
To find the base four equivalent of the decimal number $123_{10}$, we need to convert it to base four by repeatedly dividing by four and keeping track of the remainders.

Starting with $123_{10}$, we divide by four to get:
$$123 \div 4 = 30 \text{ remainder } 3$$

Next, we divide 30 by four to get:
$$30 \div 4 = 7 \text{ remainder } 2$$

Lastly, we divide 7 by four to get:
$$7 \div 4 = 1 \text{ remainder } 3$$

We can write out the remainders in reverse order to get the base four equivalent of $123_{10}$, which is $323_4$.
